It is a [[Canada]]-South Africa co-production. It first aired in Canada on [[CBC Television]] on 13 October 2006, and in South Africa on [[SABC3]] in 2007. Producers are Morula Pictures (South Africa) and Inner City Films Inc. (Canada). The series was co-created by South Africans Mfundi Vundla and Karen Briner. Currently being shown on OH-TV, Sky Digital channel 199. ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310145806/http://www.jozih.com/ Jozi-H official website] * {{IMDb title | id=0835462 | name=Jozi-H }} * {{tv.com show|jozi-h|Jozi-H}} * [http://www.tvsa.co.za/mastershowinfo.asp?mastershowid=1223 TVSA's Jozi-H Mini-Site] * [http://www.canoe.tv First 6 episodes available for free viewing under Drama category] [[Category:2006 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:2007 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:2000s Canadian drama television series]] [[Category:CBC Television shows]] [[Category:Canadian medical television series]] [[Category:South African drama television series]] [[Category:SABC 3 programmes]] [[Category:Television shows set in Johannesburg, South Africa]] {{drama-tv-prog-stub}} {{SouthAfrica-tv-stub}}

{{Distinguish|Khnum}} Among the [[Nenets people]] of [[Siberia]], the male '''Num''' was the sky god, the good creator of earth and the high god of the Nenets. Num is one of two [[demiurge]]s, or supreme gods. The Nenets believed earth and all living things were created by the god Num and every heavenly sphere is ruled by one son of the Num god. [[Nga (god)|Nga]] was his malevolent son.
According to one story, the world threatened to collapse on itself. To try to halt this cataclysm a [[shaman]] sought the advice of [[Num (God)|Num]]. The shaman was advised to travel below the earth, to Nga's domain and call upon him. The shaman did as told and was wed with Nga's daughter. After that point he began to support the world in his hand and became known as "The Old Man of the Earth."
In another myth, Num and Nga create the world, collaborating and also competing with each other — the myth is an example of [[dualistic cosmology]].<ref>Vértes 1990: 104–105</ref>
The word Num means heaven in [[Nenets languages|Nenets]].
==See also==
* [[Nga (god)]] * [[Pole worship]]
== Notes ==
<references/>
==Sources== * {{cite book |last=Vértes |first=Edit |title=Szibériai nyelvrokonaink hitvilága |publisher=Tankönyvkiadó |location=Budapest |year=1990 |isbn=963-18-2603-1 |language=Hungarian}} The title means: “Belief systems of our language relatives in Siberia”.
[[Category:Nenets people]] [[Category:Siberian deities]] [[Category:Creator gods]]

{{otheruses|Orbita, Spain}} {{unreferenced|date=July 2014}} '''Orbita''' ({{lang-ru|орбита}}) is a Soviet-Russian [[system]] of broadcasting and delivering [[TV]] signals via satellites. It is considered to be the first national [[television network|network]] of [[satellite television]]. [[File:Орбита в Хабаровске лето 1977.jpg|thumb|Orbita ground station. [[Khabarovsk]]. 1977]] The Orbita system is based on [[communication satellite]]s in highly elliptical [[Molniya orbit]]s, as well as on many ground [[downlink]] TV stations for reception and relaying TV [[Signalling (telecommunication)|signal]]s to [[Antenna (radio)|antennas]] of TV sets of many local areas. The full deployment of the Orbita satellite system took place on 25 October 1967 when ground [[downlink]] stations of some cities of Soviet [[Siberia]] and the Far East began to receive regular TV programmes from Moscow-based [[uplink]] [[Ground station|station]]s via a [[Satellite constellation|constellation]] of [[Molniya (satellite)|Molniya satellites]].
==External links== *[http://www.fas.org/spp/guide/russia/comm/elliptical/molniya.htm Molniya satellites : the description] *[http://www.friends-partners.org/partners/mwade/craft/molniya1.htm Molniya satellites] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20041031045047/http://english.pravda.ru/culture/2001/10/01/16678.html Russian TV celebrates 70th Anniversary] *[http://reference.allrefer.com/country-guide-study/soviet-union/soviet-union390.html Communications] *[http://www.fas.org/irp/imint/docs/rst/AppA/Part1_14.html Earth Application Satellites]
[[Category:Communications satellites]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Television in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Satellite television]]
{{communications-satellite-stub}}

of the [[Portuguese Empire]] |era = |year_start = 1482 |year_end = 1642 |date_start = 21 January |date_end = 9 January |event_start = |event_end = |p1 = |flag_p1 = |s1 = Dutch Gold Coast |flag_s1 = Flag of the Dutch West India Company.svg |image_flag = Flag Portugal (1640).svg |flag = |image_coat = Coat of arms of Portugal (1640).svg |symbol = |image_map = |image_map_caption = |capital = [[São Jorge da Mina]] |latd = |common_languages = [[Portuguese Language|Portuguese]] |title_leader = Head of state |leader1 = [[John II of Portugal]] |year_leader1 = [[List of Portuguese monarchs|King]]
   1482–1495 (first) |leader2 = [[John IV of Portugal]] |year_leader2 = [[List of Portuguese monarchs|King]]
   1640–1642 (last) |title_representative = [[Captain-major]] |representative1 = Diogo de Azambuja |year_representative1 = 1482–1484 (first) |representative2 = António da Rocha Magalhães |year_representative2 = 1634–1642 (last) |title_deputy = |deputy1 = |year_deputy1 = |deputy2 = |year_deputy2 = |religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] |currency = }} {{Gold Coast (Ghana)}} The '''Portuguese Gold Coast''' was a [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese colony]] on the West African [[Gold Coast (region)|Gold Coast]] (present-day [[Ghana]]) on the [[Gulf of Guinea]]. ==History== The [[Portugal|Portuguese]] established the following settlements on the Gold Coast from 21 January 1482: * Fort São Jorge da Mina de Ouro, modern [[Elmina]]: 21 January 1482 – 28–9 August 1637; this became the capital * [[Fort Santo Antonio|Fort Santo António]] de Axim, modern [[Axim]]: 1486 – 1642 * Fort São Francisco Xavier, modern [[Osu, Accra|Osu]], district of [[Accra]]: 1640–1642 * Fort São Sebastião, modern [[Shama, Ghana|Shama]]: 1526–1637. On 29 August 1637 the Dutch occupied São Jorge da Mina. On 9 January 1642 the whole colony was ceded to the Dutch, who made it part of their [[Dutch Gold Coast]] colony. ==Captains-major== The Portuguese governors, going by this modest, military style, were: *1482 – 1485 - [[Diogo de Azambuja]] *1485 – 1486 - Álvaro Vaz Pestano *148? – Álvaro Mascarenhas *c.1487 – João Fogaça *1495 – 1499 - [[Lopo Soares de Albergaria]] *1499? – 1503? - Fernão Lopes Correia *1503? – 1506? - [[Diogo Lopes de Sequeira]] *1506? – 1509? - António de Bobadilha *c.1510 – Manuel de Góis *1513 – Afonso Caldeira *c.1513 – António Fróis{{cite book|author=Wilks, Ivor. Wangara, Akan, and Portuguese in the Fifteenth and Sixteenth Centuries|editor1-last=Bakewell|editor1-first=Peter|title=Mines of Silver and Gold in the Americas|date=1997|publisher=Variorum, Ashgate Publishing Limited|location=Aldershot|pages=24}} *1514 – 1516? - Nuno Vaz de Castelo Branco *1516? – 1519 - Fernão Lopes Correia *1519 – 1522 - [[Duarte Pacheco Pereira]] *1522 – 1524 - Afonso de Albuquerque *1524 – 1525 - [[João de Barros]]{{rp|26}} *1526 – 1529 - João Vaz de Almada *1529 – 1532 - [[Estêvão da Gama (16th century)|Estêvão da Gama]] *1536 – 1537 - Manuel de Albuquerque *1537 – 1540? - .... *1540 – 1543 - António de Miranda de Azevedo *1541 – 1545? - Lopo de Sousa Coutinho *1545 – Diogo Soares de Albergaria (1st time) *1545 – 1548 - António de Brito *1548 – 1550 - Lopo de Sousa Coutinho{{rp|30}} *1550? – 162? - Luís Tomé de Castro *162? – 1629 - João da Serra de Morais *1629 – c.1632 - .... *1632 – 1634 - Pedro de Mascarenhas *1634 – 1634 - Duarte Borges (acting) *1634 – 1642 - André da Rocha Magalhães (acting) *1642 – 1642 - Francisco de Sotte ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.worldstatesmen.org/Ghana.html#Portuguse%20Gold WorldStatesmen.org: Portuguese Gold Coast] {{Gold Coast}} {{Portuguese overseas empire}} {{Ghana topics}} {{coord missing|Ghana}} {{Clear}} [[Category:Portuguese Gold Coast| ]] [[Category:History of Ghana]] [[Category:Former colonies in Africa]] [[Category:Former Portuguese colonies|Gold Coast]] [[Category:Portuguese colonisation in Africa|Gold Coast]] [[Category:History of West Africa|Portuguese Gold Coast]] [[Category:15th century in Ghana]] [[Category:16th century in Ghana]] [[Category:17th century in Ghana]] [[Category:15th century in the Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:16th century in the Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:17th century in the Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:15th-century establishments in Africa]] [[Category:1642 disestablishments in Africa]] [[Category:1482 establishments in the Portuguese Empire]] [[Category:1642 disestablishments in the Portuguese Empire]] {{-}} {{Africa-hist-stub}} {{Portugal-hist-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Archdiocese | name = Zagreb | latin = Archidioecesis Zagrebiensis | local = Zagrebačka nadbiskupija | image = The Zagreb Cathedral being restored, the spires are 108m. high (13023470563).jpg | image_size = 220px | image_alt = | caption = Zagreb Cathedral | country = {{flag|Croatia}} | metropolitan = [[Zagreb]] | territory = | province = | coordinates = | area_km2 = 13,495 | population = {{profit}}1,239,708 | population_as_of = 2014 | catholics = {{loss}}1,081,539 | catholics_percent = {{loss}}87.2 | parishes = 203 | churches = | congregations = | schools = | members = | denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | established = 1093 | cathedral = [[Zagreb Cathedral|Cathedral of the Assumption of Mary]] | cocathedral = | patron = [[Aloysius Stepinac|Blessed Alojzije Stepinac]] | priests = | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} | bishop_title = Archbishop | bishop = [[Josip Bozanić]] | coadjutor = | auxiliary_bishops = [[Ivan Šaško]]
[[Mijo Gorski]] | vicar_general = | emeritus_bishops = | map = | map_alt = | map_caption = | website = [http://zg-nadbiskupija.hr/ zg-nadbiskupija.hr] | footnotes = }} The '''[[Roman Catholic]] Archdiocese of Zagreb''' ({{lang-hr|Zagrebačka nadbiskupija}}, {{lang-la|Archidioecesis Zagrebiensis}}) is the central [[archdiocese]] of the [[Catholic Church in Croatia]], centered in the capital city [[Zagreb]].[http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dzagr.html Archdiocese of Zagreb], catholic-hierarchy.org. It is the [[metropolitan see]] of Croatia, and the present archbishop is [[Josip Bozanić]].[http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/zagr0.htm Metropolitan Archdiocese of Zagreb], gcatholic.org. It encompasses the northwestern continental areas of Croatia. ==Suffragan dioceses== [[File:Nadbiskupski dvor Zagreb.jpg|thumb|Archbishop's Palace in Zagreb]] * [[Diocese of Bjelovar-Križevci|Roman Catholic Diocese of Bjelovar-Križevci]] * [[Eparchy of Križevci]] ''([[Croatian Greek Catholic Church|Greek-Catholic]])'' * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sisak]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Varaždin]] ==Origin== The diocese of Zagreb was founded by [[Ladislaus I of Hungary|Saint Ladislaus I of Hungary]] in 1093.{{fact|date=August 2014}} On November 11, 1852, it was elevated to the status of an archdiocese. ==Ordinaries== ;Bishops * [[Philip Türje]] (1247–1262) * [[Timothy, Bishop of Zagreb|Timothy]] (1263–1287) * [[Michael Bő]] (1295–1303) * [[Augustin Kažotić]] (1303–1323) * [[Nicholas II Vásári|Nicholas Vásári]] (1349) * [[Nicholas Apáti]] (1350–1356) * [[Paul Horvat]] (1379–1386) * Thomas de Branche de Debrentha (11 October 1454 – 13 January 1463) * [[Nicolaus Olahus]] (1543–1548) * [[Juraj Drašković]] (22 March 1564 – 27 October 1578) * [[Nikola Stepanić Selnički]] (1598–1602) * Miklós Zelniczey Naprady (15 December 1600 – 1604) * Šimun Bratulić (13 September 1604 – 1611) * Petar Domitrović (15 July 1613 – 1629) * Franjo Ergelski Hasanović (17 December 1629 – 1642) * [[Benedikt Vinković]] (28 April 1642 – 1643) * Martin Bogdan (1643–1647) * [[Petar Petretić]] (1648 – 3 August 1667) * Martin Borković (11 June 1668 – 31 October 1687) * Aleksandar Ignacije Mikulić Brokunovečki (11 October 1688 – 11 May 1694) * Stjepan Seliščević (10 January 1695 – 1 April 1703) * Márton Brajkovićs (14 January 1704 – 4 June 1708) * Imre Esterházy (9 September 1709 – 17 March 1727) * Juraj Branjug (26 November 1727 – 28 April 1748) * Franjo Klobusiczky (2 December 1748 – 20 Dec Mihalović]] (27 June 1870 – 19 February 1891) * [[Juraj Posilović]] (18 May 1894 – 26 April 1914) * [[Antun Bauer (Archbishop)|Antun Bauer]] (26 April 1914 – 9 December 1937) * [[Alojzije Stepinac]] (7 December 1937 – 10 February 1960) * [[Franjo Šeper]] (5 March 1960 – 20 August 1969) * [[Franjo Kuharić]] (16 June 1970 – 5 July 1997) * [[Josip Bozanić]] (5 July 1997 – present) ==References== page.title: Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Saint Joseph at Irkutsk |latin = Dioecesis Ircutscana Sancti Iosephi |local = Епархия Святого Иосифа в Иркутске |image = Собор Непорочного Сердца Божией Матери (Иркутск) 003.jpg |caption = [[Immaculate Heart of Mary Cathedral, Irkutsk|Cathedral of the Immaculate Heart of Mary]] |country = Russia |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = Cathedral of the Immaculate Heart of Mary |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 9,960,000 |population = 15,500,000 |population_as_of = 2004 |catholics = 52,000 |catholics_percent= 0.3 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Cyryl Klimowicz]] |map =Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk.PNG }}
The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk''' ({{lang-la|Ircutscana Sancti Iosephi}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Irkutsk]], which is part of the [[ecclesiastical province]] of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mother of God at Moscow]] in [[Russia]]. The Diocese of Irkutsk is in fact the largest geographical Catholic bishopric on earth, covering an area of 9,960,000 km2.
==History== * May 18, 1999: Established as Apostolic Administration of Siberia Orientale from Apostolic Administration of Siberia * February 11, 2002: Promoted as Diocese of Saint Joseph (located at San Giuseppe an Irkutsk)
==Special churches== *Former cathedral **[[Mother of God Church, Vladivostok|Church of the Most Holy Mother of God]] in [[Vladivostok]], [[Russia]]
==Episcopal ordinaries== (all [[Roman Rite]])
=== Apostolic Administrators of Siberia Orientale === * [[Jerzy Mazur]], [[Society of the Divine Word|SVD]] (18 May 1999 – 11 February 2002)
=== Bishops of Saint Joseph at Irkutsk === # [[Jerzy Mazur]], SVD (11 February 2002 – 17 April 2003) # [[Cyryl Klimowicz]] (17 April 2003 – )
==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Russia]] *[[List of Roman Catholic dioceses in Russia]] *[[Immaculate Heart of Mary Cathedral, Irkutsk]]
==Sources== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/zjos8.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dirku.html Catholic Hierarchy]
{{coord missing|Russia}}

{{About|the term "Taiwan, China"|the state commonly known as "Taiwan"|Taiwan|the Taiwan Province governed by the Republic of China|Taiwan Province|the hypothetical Taiwan Province that is claimed but not governed by the People's Republic of China|Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China}} {{other uses2|Taiwan}} {{See also|Cross-Strait relations}} {{Multiple issues| {{original research|date=December 2016}} {{more citations needed|date=June 2014}} }} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} {{Infobox Chinese | title = Taiwan, China | pic =File:China map.png | picsize =360px | piccap = Territory controlled by the [[China|People's Republic of China]] (purple) and the [[Taiwan|Republic of China]] (orange). The size of minor islands have been exaggerated in this map for ease of identification. | t = {{linktext|中國|臺灣}} | s = {{linktext|中国|台湾}} | p = Zhōngguó Táiwān |psp=Chungkuo Taiwan |bpmf=ㄓㄨㄥ ㄍㄨㄛˊ ㄊㄞˊ ㄨㄢ |w= Chung<sup>1</sup>-kuo<sup>2</sup> T'ai²-wan¹ |tp= Jhongguó Táiwan |mi={{IPAc-cmn|zh|ong|1|.|g|uo|2}} {{IPAc-cmn|t|ai|2|.|wan|1}} |gr=Jong'gwo Tair'uan |hsn=Tan<sup>33</sup>-kwɛ<sup>24</sup>/ dwɛ<sup>13</sup> ua<sup>44</sup> |poj=Tiong-kok Tâi-oân |h=Dung<sup>24</sup>-gued<sup>2</sup> Thòi-vàn |buc=Dṳ̆ng-guók Dài-uăng |j=Zung1-gwok3 Toi4waan1 |y=Jūng-gwok Tòiwāan |wuu=Tson<sup>平</sup>-koh<sup>入</sup> The<sup>平</sup>-uae<sup>平</sup> |mnc=ᠠᡳᠸᠠᠨ ᠵᡠᠨᡤᠣ |mnc_rom=Taiwan Jungg'o |mong=ᠲᠠᠶᠢᠪᠠᠨᠢ ᠬᠢᠲᠠᠳ |mon={{longitem|Тайвань Хятад }} |monr=Taivan Khyatad |zha=Daizvanh Cunggoz | tib = {{bo-textonly|ཐའེ་ཝན, ཀྲུང་གོ་}} | wylie = Tha'e wan, Krung-go | uig = جۇڭگو,تەيۋەن | uly = Teywen, Junggo | usy = Тейвен, Җунгго | altname = Taiwan, Province of China | t2 = {{linktext|中國|臺灣省}} | s2 = {{linktext|中国|台湾省}} | p2 = Zhōngguó Táiwānshěng }}
'''"Taiwan, China"'''<!-- Please do not add official regional/minority languages here; use the langbox template directly above, included specifically for that purpose. -->, '''"Taiwan, Province of China"''', or '''"Taiwan Province, China"''' are a set of politically controversial and potentially ambiguous terms that characterize [[free area of the Republic of China|Taiwan and its associated territories]] as a [[provinces of China|province]] or territory of "[[China]]". The term, "Taiwan, China" is used by [[Media of China|Chinese media]] whenever Taiwan is referenced by [[media in China|Chinese media]]. In English, "China" is inserted after "Taiwan" by adding {{nowrap|", China"}}, per English grammar rules. In the [[Chinese language]], however, the [[Chinese characters]] {{lang|zh-hant|中國}} ("China") would be inserted in front of "{{lang|zh-hant|台灣}}" (Taiwan) per Chinese convention to indicate a country and its subdivisions. For example, the word "China" would be inserted into [[subtitle (captioning)|video captions]] on television, whenever a person mentions the word "Taiwan" but the characters {{lang|zh-hant|中國}} ("China") would be inserted in front of "Taiwan" ({{lang|zh-hant|台灣}}) despite the fact that the person never said the word "China", to [[propaganda|propagandize]] to the world that Taiwan is part of ''China''. (Video subtitling is standard practice in the Chinese language due to the existence of many mutually unintelligible "[[Chinese dialects]]".) The term "Taiwan, Province of China" also sometimes appears in the [[drop-down list|drop-down menu]] of websites and computer software that show a list of [[ISO 3166-1|ISO 3166-1 country names]] (see UN and ISO section below).<ref name="ISO">{{cite web|url=http://taiwanmatters.blogspot.com/2010/05/how-iso-helps-china-change-taiwans.html| title=How the ISO helps China change Taiwan's status quo}}</ref>
The terms are contentious and potentially [[ambiguity|ambiguous]] because they relate to the controversial issues of the [[political status of Taiwan]] and [[Cross-Strait relations]] between "Taiwan" and "China", in that whether they are two separate countries or "two areas of one country". Since 1949, [[two Chinas|two countries with the name "China" (Two Chinas)]] actually exist, namely the [[Taiwan|Republic of China]] (ROC, founded 1912 and now commonly known as "[[Taiwan]]") and the [[China|People's Republic of China]] (PRC, founded 1949 and now commonly known as "[[China]]", and "''the'' China"). However, only one "China" actually rules [[Taiwan]], namely Republic of China, and has an administrative division called "[[Taiwan Province]]" but refers to it as "Taiwan Province, Republic of China"; whereas, the other "China", namely the People's Republic of China, which is the one [[diplomatic recognition|internationally recognized]] as "China" (not the ROC), ''claims'' but does not control [[free area of the Republic of China|Taiwan]] as part of its territory.
The juxtaposition of "Taiwan" and "China" in this order into one single term "Taiwan, China" implicitly places the Taiwan under the sovereignty of PRC/"China", in the same sense as "California, USA". The use of this term is officially and politically sanctioned by the [[Communist Party of China|Communist Chinese]] government as a way to claim and [[propaganda|propagandize]] that Taiwan is under its [[sovereignty]],<ref name="CCTV">{{cite web|url=http://www.liuqiu-china.com/portal.php?mod=view&aid=1094|script-title=zh:请央视自律 关于正确使用涉台宣传用语的意见}}</ref> since the PRC claims to be the [[legitimacy (political)|legitimate government]] of "all China", which, according to its own definition, includes Taiwan also, despite its lack of control. Some of the [[Government of the Republic of China|ROC government]] disputes the PRC position and it, along with Many of the [[Taiwanese people]], considers this term incorrect and offensive, in that its use is a lie which denies the ROC's sovereignty and existence, reducing Taiwan's status to a province of the PRC (see "[[Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China|Taiwan, PRC]]"), and objects to its use.<ref name="ROC May16">{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110517/wl_asia_afp/taiwanchinadiplimacywho| title=Taiwan protests "province of China" WHO label}}</ref> The term is particularly offensive to supporters of [[Taiwan independence movement|Taiwan Independence]] and want to [[Taiwanization|disassociate]] Taiwan with "China" and a [[Chinese culture|Chinese identity]], (i.e., [[de-Sinicization|de-Sinicize]]), and consider it an [[oxymoron]], [[Id est|i.e.]] in the view that Taiwan and China are different countries, and that the [[legitimacy (political)|legitimacy]] of the ROC's rule of Taiwan is disputed in the first place.
== Background and ambiguity over "China" == {{Further|Chinese Civil War}}
The dispute and ambiguity over the meaning of "China" and which "China" stemmed from the division of [[Republic of China (1912-1949)|Republic of China]] into [[two Chinas]] at the "end" of the [[Chinese Civil War]] in 1955.{{efn|There is some debate whether the war has ended since the two Chinas are still fighting for international recognition and assurance of sovereignty. See [[Chinese Civil War]] for details.}} (Fighting between the two merely eased off after 1949 and no signing of a [[peace treaty]] or [[armistice]] ever occurred; the PRC still threatens attack on ROC/Taiwan when it deems necessary.) The term "China" historically meant the various regimes and imperial dynasties which controlled territories in mainland Asia prior to 1911, when the imperial system was overthrown and the Republic of China (ROC) was established as the first republic in Asia. In 1927, the Chinese Civil War started between the [[Kuomintang]] (KMT, founding party of the ROC) and the [[Communist Party of China]], a rebel force at the time. The Chinese Communists eventually won control of most of ROC's original territory ([[mainland China]]) in 1949, when they proclaimed the "People's Republic of China" (PRC) on that territory.
Since then, two Chinas have existed, although the PRC was not internationally recognized at the time. The Republic of China government, who received [[Geography of Taiwan|Taiwan]] in 1945 from [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] then fled in 1949 to Taiwan with the aim to retake mainland China and retained the name "Republic of China". Both the ROC and the PRC still officially (constitutionally) claim mainland China and the [[Free area of the Republic of China|Taiwan Area]] as part of their respective territories. In reality, the PRC rules only Mainland China and has no control of but claims Taiwan as part of its territory under its "[[One-China Policy|One China Principle]]". The ROC, which only rules the [[Taiwan Area]] (composed of [[Geography of Taiwan|Taiwan]] and [[List of islands of the Republic of China|its nearby minor islands]]), became known as "Taiwan" after its largest island, (an instance of ''[[pars pro toto]]''). It stopped active claim of mainland China as part of its territory after [[Constitution of the Republic of China|constitutional]]<nowiki/> reform in 1991.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sino.gov.tw/en/show_issue.php?id=200068906052e.txt&cur_page=2&table=2&distype=&h1=About%20Taiwan&h2=Politics&search=&height=&type=&scope=&order=&keyword=&lstPage=&num=&year=2000&month=06 | title = A Pivotal President-- Lee Teng-hui's 12 Years | publisher = Taiwan Panorama (Sino)| date = 2000-06-05}}</ref>
However, since the 2008 election of [[Ma Ying-jeou]], he again asserted that [[mainland China]] is part of Republic of China territory according to its constitution, and, in 2013, he stated that [[Cross-strait relations|relations between PRC and ROC]] are not between countries but "regions of the same country".<ref>{{cite news |title = Taiwan and China in 'special relations': Ma |publisher = China Post |date = 2008-09-04 |url = http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/china-taiwan%20relations/2008/09/04/173082/Taiwan-and.htm}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.chinasmack.com/2013/stories/taiwan-president-mainland-china-is-still-our-territory.html |title =Taiwan President: Mainland China is Still Our Territory |publisher = ChinaSmack |date = 2013-10-29}}</ref>
In 1971, the People's Republic of China won the [[United Nations General Assembly Resolution 2758|United Nations seat as "China"]] and use of the name and expelled the ROC from the UN. Since then the term "Taiwan, China" is a designation typically used in international organizations like the United Nations and its associated organs under pressure from the PRC to accommodate its claim and to give the false impression that Taiwan belongs to the PRC. (The term "[[Chinese Taipei]]" was similarly created for the same purpose.) However, the [[political status of Taiwan]] is a complex and controversial issue and currently unresolved, in large part due to the United States and the [[Allies of World War II]] handling of the [[surrender of Japan|surrender of Taiwan from Japan]] in 1945 (which was to be a [[General Order No. 1|temporary administration]] by the ROC troops), and the [[Treaty of Peace with Japan]] ("Treaty of San Francisco") in 1951, for which neither the ROC nor the PRC was invited, and left Taiwan's sovereignty legally undefined in [[international law]] and [[political status of Taiwan|in dispute]].
== Ambiguity of "Taiwan Province" == {{Main|Taiwan Province}} The term "Taiwan, (Province of) China" is also potentially ambiguous because both the ROC and the PRC each has administratively a "Taiwan Province", [[Taiwan Province|Taiwan Province, Republic of China]] and "[[Taiwan Province, People's Republic of China]]", and neither of these provinces covers the Matsu Islands, Wuchiu, Kinmen, all of which have been retained by the Republic of China. Geographically speaking, they both refer to the same place. The existence of the extra term "Taiwan Province, PRC" is merely because of PRC's insistence that Taiwan is part of China. Without more specific indication, it is unclear to which "Taiwan Province" is being referred. However, since China (PRC) does not control Taiwan and its "Taiwan Province" exists only on paper, as a practical matter, "Taiwan Province" refers only to the Taiwan Province under Republic of China's administration.
Although the word "China" could also possibly be interpreted to mean "Republic of China", this interpretation is no longer common since "China" is typically understood as referring to the PRC after the ROC lost its [[China and the United Nations|UN seat as "China"]] in 1971, and is considered a term distinct from "Taiwan", the name with which the ROC has become identified. Also, only the ROC's Taiwan Province exists in reality and is under the ROC's actual territorial control, whereas the PRC's "Taiwan Province" exists only on paper, under the PRC's administrative structure but without an actual provincial government. Instead, the PRC has a [[Taiwan Affairs Office|Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council]] to deal with issues and policy guidelines relating to Taiwan.
The ROC also does not refer to its Taiwan Province as "Taiwan, China" in English but rather as "Taiwan Province, Republic of China" ({{zh|labels=no |t=中華民國臺灣省 |p=Zhōnghuá Mínguó Táiwānshěng}}), and typically such reference only occurs in the [[Chinese language]] in the ROC's official documents and as the marquee in the administrative offices of Taiwan Province government. However, references to the province is now rare since the [[Taiwan Provincial Government]] has largely been dissolved and its functions transferred to the central government or county governments since 1997. Therefore, recent uses of the term "Taiwan, Province of China" appears mainly in PRC-controlled media like CCTV ([[Chinese Central Television]]) and in the [[ISO 3166-1]] codes to convey the sense that Taiwan is part of ''its'' "China".<ref name="CCTV"/>
== Objections == === ROC (Taiwan) government === Although the Republic of China is no longer a member of the United Nations, the term "Taiwan, China" has sometimes been used by the U.N. to refer to the Republic of China.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/2003_12_17/en/index.html| title=Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) in Taiwan, China | work=World Health Organization|date=2003-12-17}}</ref> (The ROC is prohibited from using its official name internationally under pressure from the PRC and uses "[[Chinese Taipei]]" in other organizations.) The ROC sees its use as a denial of the ROC's status as a separate sovereign state, diminishing it under "China", which implicitly is the PRC. Various instances of the use of the term by international organizations or news media have been met with protest from the Taiwanese government officials and citizens.
In an incident on 10 May 2011, the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), an [[List of specialized agencies of the United Nations|agency]] of the UN, referred to Taiwan as "Taiwan, China" in its documents. (The ROC participates in the WHO under the name "[[Chinese Taipei]]", due to political pressure from the PRC.) ROC president [[Ma Ying-jeou]] protested the WHO's action and accused the PRC of "pressuring the UN body into calling" the ROC "Chinese territory", and stated that Beijing's moves were "very negative" for [[Cross-strait relations|bilateral ties]].<ref name="ROC Protest">{{cite news |url=http://www2.readingeagle.com/article.aspx?id=306900|title=Taiwan president protests China pressuring UN body into calling island a Chinese territory|work=The Associated Press|publisher=Reading Eagle|date=2011-05-10|accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> Ma, who took office in 2008, has taken many measures to improve [[Cross-Strait relations]].
=== Taiwan Independence Supporters === {{Further|Taiwan independence}} The confusion and fight over use of the "China" name and the lack of name recognition of "Republic of China" itself and [[Political status of Taiwan|recognition as a country]] are part of the reason for the supporters of [[Taiwan independence]] to push for an identity apart from "China" and for renaming the ROC and gaining [[diplomatic recognition|international recognition]] as "[[Taiwan independence movement|Republic of Taiwan]]". Some supporters also reject the [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimacy of Republic of China]]'s takeover of Taiwan from Japan at the end of World War II since 1945 (due to the lack of transfer of sovereignty in the [[Treaty of Peace with Japan]]). They also view that Taiwan is no longer part of China since "China" is recognized by the UN as being the People's Republic of China (PRC) rather than the ROC/Taiwan, so placing "Taiwan" and "China" together in one term is not only incorrect and an [[oxymoron]] but also offensively denies the ROC's national [[sovereignty]] and existence and places it under China.
== Usage == === The United Nations and the ISO === The term "Taiwan, Province of China" also appears in the [[International Organization for Standardization]]'s [[ISO 3166-1]] country codes because its information source, the publication ''UN Terminology Bulletin-Country Names'', lists Taiwan as "Taiwan, Province of China" due to the PRC's political influence in the United Nations as a member of the [[UN Security Council]]. Since the ISO 3166-1 code is commonly used as the data source for a complete list of country and territory names for computer programs and websites, "Taiwan, Province of China" is sometimes seen on [[dropdown menu]]s instead of "Taiwan" for this reason.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lin|first1=Keng-yu|last2=Tsai|first2=Rex|title=Taiwan listed as "Taiwan, Province of China"|url=https://bugs.launchpad.net/developer-ubuntu-com/+bug/885293|website=[[Launchpad (website)|Launchpad]]|publisher=Canonical Ltd.|accessdate=17 September 2016|date=2 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/170143/taiwan-is-not-a-province-of-china|title=Taiwan is not a province of China}}</ref>
=== People's Republic of China === The term is often used in Chinese media whenever the word "''Taiwan''" is mentioned, as in news reports and in TV shows. Particularly, when Taiwanese entertainers are on talk shows or being interviewed, the Chinese subtitles on the TV screen would always say "Taiwan, China" ({{lang|zh-hans|中国台湾}} / {{lang|zh-hant|中國台灣}}) despite the fact the person never mentioned the word "China" ({{lang|zh-hans|中国}} / {{lang|zh-hant|中國}}), thereby putting words in the person's mouth.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mangapower|url= http://www.want-daily.com/portal.php?mod=view&aid=81393 |title=Pressured by "higher-ups paying attention", so UNI Yeh said "Taipei, China"|publisher=Apple Daily (in Chinese)|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref> (It is standard practice for Chinese television to display [[Subtitle (captioning)|subtitles]] in all programs.) Also, there has been controversy about Chinese [[talent show]]s forcing Taiwanese contestants to introduce themselves as from "Taiwan, China" or from "[[Chinese Taipei]]." For example, Taiwanese singer [[:zh:葉瑋庭|Uni Yeh]], on her first appearance on the [[Voice of China]], introduced herself as being from "Pingtung District, China Taipei," which caused an uproar among Taiwanese [[netizens]]. Her response was that she was instructed to say so by the directors and was nervous.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jianhong Wu|url= http://m.ent.appledaily.com.tw/section/article/entertainment/20130721/35164847 |title=UNI Yeh self-introduction blunder of "Pingtung, China" on "Voice of China" criticized |publisher=Apple Daily (in Chinese)|accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
=== United States === If a place of birth on a [[United States passport]] application is written as "Taiwan, China" that cannot be shown in passports per [[One-China Policy]], the [[United States Department of State]] requires its officials to contact the applicant to ascertain whether "Taiwan" or "China" is preferred place of birth to be printed.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://fam.state.gov/FAM/08FAM/08FAM040304.html |title=8 FAM 403.4 Place of Birth |last= |first= |date=2018-06-27 |website=Foreign Affairs Manual |publisher=United States Department of State |access-date=2018-07-18 |quote="d. If an applicant born in Taiwan writes "Taiwan, China" as her/his POB on a passport application, you must contact the applicant to ascertain whether she/he prefers either TAIWAN or CHINA as her/his POB (Information Request Letter 707-06)." "f. Passports may not be issued showing the POB as "Taiwan, China," "Taiwan, Republic of China," or "Taiwan, ROC.""}}</ref>
=== Vietnam === In [[Vietnam]], most government documents and many state media<ref>{{cite web|language=vi |author=Trần Nga theo Ap |url=http://vov.vn/Home/Dai-Loan-Trung-Quoc-quyen-gop-26-trieu-USD-cho-Nhat-Ban/20113/169764.vov |title=Đài Loan, Trung Quốc quyên góp 26 triệu USD cho Nhật Bản |publisher=Vov.vn |accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://moj.gov.vn/Pages/thoiquoctich.aspx |title=Danh Sách Công Dân Việt Nam Được Thôi Quốc Tịch Việt Nam |publisher=Moj.gov.vn |date=25 March 2005 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref> usually use the forms {{lang|vi|Đài Loan (Trung Quốc)}} ["Taiwan (China)"] or {{lang|vi|Đài Loan, Trung Quốc}} ("Taiwan, China") to refer to Taiwan or Republic of China in many contexts, including in music and entertainment coverage.<ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://www.vietnamplus.vn/trung-quoc-dai-loan-khai-truong-trien-lam-den-long/35935.vnp |title=Trung Quốc, Đài Loan khai trương triển lãm đèn lồng |publisher=vietnamplus.vn |date=2010-02-12 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref><ref>[http://www.svhttdl.hochiminhcity.gov.vn/web/guest/tin-tuc-su-kien/du-lich?p_p_id=EXT_ARTICLEVIEW&p_p_lifecycle=0&p_p_state=normal&p_p_col_id=column-1&p_p_col_count=1&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_struts_action=%2Fext%2Farticleview%2Fview&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_delta=20&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_keywords=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_advancedSearch=false&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_andOperator=true&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_groupId=16&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_searchArticleId=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_version=1.0&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_title=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_description=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_content=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_type=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_structureId=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_templateId=&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_status=approved&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_orderByCol=display-date&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_orderByType=desc&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_articleId=39139&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_i=35&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_curValue=0&_EXT_ARTICLEVIEW_redirect=%2Fweb%2Fguest&cur=10 VietNam Airlines tổ chức đoàn khảo sát điểm đến Đài Loan (Trung Quốc)]</ref><ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://www.vietnamplus.vn/Home/Di-nu-Lady-Gaga-khuay-dong-thi-truong-Dai-Loan/20117/95838.vnplus |title=Dị nữ Lady Gaga khuấy động thị trường Đài Loan |publisher=Vietnamplus.vn |date=9 November 2008 |accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref> In other media, they often use the term {{lang|vi|vùng lãnh thổ}} ("territory")<ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://www.baodatviet.vn/the-gioi/dai-loan-dung-suc-manh-mem-chong-trung-quoc-dai-loan-dung-suc-manh-mem-chong-trung-quoc-2273551/ |title=Đài Loan dùng sức mạnh mềm chống Trung Quốc? |publisher=Baodatviet.vn |date=2010-10-25 |accessdate=2013-12-04}}</ref> or {{lang|vi|đảo}} ("island")<ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://vtc.vn/311-260167/quoc-te/ten-lua-hsiungfeng-2e-cua-dao-dai-loan-co-gi-manh.htm |title=Tên lửa Hsiungfeng 2E của đảo Đài Loan có gì mạnh? |publisher=Baodatviet.vn |date=2010-10-05 |accessdate=2013-12-04 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://vtc.vn/311-260167/quoc-te/ten-lua-hsiungfeng-2e-cua-dao-dai-loan-co-gi-manh.htm |title=Tên lửa Hsiungfeng 2E của đảo Đài Loan có gì mạnh? |publisher=Vtc.vn |accessdate=29 November 2011 }}</ref> to refer to Taiwan when wanting to avoid repeating the term "Taiwan" many times in their article. The term {{lang|vi|Tỉnh Đài Loan}} ("Taiwan Province")<ref>{{cite web|language=vi |url=http://vietbao.vn/Nguoi-Viet-bon-phuong/4-nguoi-Viet-bi-bat-o-Dai-Loan/11013173/283/ |title=4 người Việt bị bắt ở Đài Loan |publisher=Vietbao.vn |accessdate=29 November 2011}}</ref> sometimes appear in media to refer to all of "[[Taiwan Area]]" (not only referring to the [[Taiwan Province]] of ROC). In general, Vietnamese state media never refer to Taiwan as a "nation" or a "state".
===International airlines=== In April, 2018, the [[China Civil Aviation Authority]], wrote a letter to 36 airlines throughout the world, including US Airlines [[Delta Airlines|Delta]], [[United Airlines|United]], and [[American Airlines|American]], Canadian airline [[Air Canada]], [[Japan Airlines]], [[ANA (airline)|ANA]], [[Air New Zealand]], [[Qantas]], etc., demanding that they change travel destination cities in Taiwan in their websites to list them under "Taiwan, Province of China", or directly list them as, for example, "[[Taipei]], China" and "[[Kaohsiung]], China".<ref>{{cite web|author=JAMES PALMER, BETHANY ALLEN-EBRAHIMIAN |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/04/27/china-threatens-u-s-airlines-over-taiwan-references-united-american-flight-beijing/ |title=China Threatens U.S. Airlines Over Taiwan References |publisher=Foreign Policy |date=27 April 2018 |accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref> Air Canada and other non-US airlines quickly complied. However, US Airlines requested a time extension to consider the issue, and replied to the China Civil Aviation Authority that they will confer with the U.S. government regarding the course of action. The White House responded by labeling the move as "Orwellian nonsense".<ref>{{cite news |title=White House: China push on Taiwan is 'Orwellian nonsense' |url=https://www.seattletimes.com/business/white-house-china-push-on-taiwan-is-orwellian-nonsense/ |accessdate=19 July 2018 |work=The Seattle Times |date=5 May 2018}}</ref> The China Civil Aviation Authority therefore extended the deadline for US airlines to July 25, 2018 for compliance.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2152459/beijings-demand-refer-china-taiwan-still-being-defied |title=Beijing's demand to refer to 'China Taiwan' still being defied by US airlines |publisher=South China Morning Post |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=5 July 2018}}</ref>{{Update inline |date=August 2018 }}
